clinicalDescription: Overview: Porous bone. A bone disease that occurs when the body loses too much bone, makes too little bone, or both. As a result, bones become weak and may break from a fall or, in serious cases, from sneezing or minor bumps. Risk factors for osteoporosis include aging, being female, low body weight, low sex hormones or menopause, smoking, and some medications. Presentation: Silent disease. Breaking a bone is often the first sign or may notice getting shorter or upper back is curving forward. Assessment: Bone density test - DEXA scan (diagnose bone loss), and imaging Plan: Prevention and treatment include calcium and vitamin D, exercise, and osteoporosis medications - BisphosphonatesPrognosis: Important to prevent falls and fractures. Is good if bone loss is detected in the early phases and proper intervention is undertaken.
